title: 105_hr973
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jesse Gray Housing Act" and includes findings and purposes. The "Jesse Gray Housing Act" aims to address the insufficient availability of rental units for lower-income families, the ineffectiveness of current federal housing assistance programs, and the burden of high rent costs on many families. The Act's purposes include ensuring affordable, safe, and sanitary rental housing for all families in the United States. The "Jesse Gray Housing Act" aims to ensure affordable, safe, and sanitary rental housing for lower-income families by limiting federal housing assistance to them and promoting the establishment of a public housing system with projects in various areas and visually similar to private units. The "Jesse Gray Housing Act" aims to provide affordable, safe, and sanitary rental housing for lower-income families through the construction of 500,000 new public housing units annually from 1998 to 2007. Funding is authorized for this program to revitalize public housing. The Jesse Gray Housing Act authorizes funding to revitalize public housing by providing financial assistance for public housing projects that were at risk of demolition or disposition. The Secretary is directed to prioritize public housing agencies requesting assistance for revitalization. The budget authority for contracts for annual contributions is increased to support the revitalization of 100,000 dwelling units in public housing each fiscal year from 1998 to 2007. SEC. 5 prohibits the demolition or disposition of any public housing project. It amends Section 18(a) of the United States Housing Act of 1937. Conforming amendments are made to Section 18, including the removal of subsections (b), (c), (e), and (f), and the redesignation of subsections (d) and (g) as subsections (b) and (c). The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to lower income housing requirements from 30 to 25 in various sections. Additionally, amendments are made to the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act and Supportive Housing for the Elderly. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 is amended to reduce income housing requirements from 30 to 25. Certain income is excluded for determining family contributions, including welfare assistance and Social Security benefits. The provisions and amendments will take effect on October 1, 1997. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will submit a report to Congress proposing to limit Federal housing assistance to public housing to ensure funds benefit lower income families.
